results.title: Lore of the land (PC & MAC)
results.creator_credit: Fraynework Multimedia, Multimedia 21 Fund - Cinemedia and Adele Howard
results.brief_description: The land we live in shapes our lives and holds the story of our relationship with its vast mystery. This CD ROM is an invitation to explore and understand the Aboriginal love of the land. Take a journey through new cultural insights, Australian landscapes and Indigenous voices. It is designed to encourage us to live in harmony with each other and with the land we call home. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: Power Macintosh system 7.6.6 or later, 32MB RAM, 40 MB free HD space, 640 X 480 display (set to thousands of colours), 4 X CD ROM or better. IBM PC and Compatible: Pentium 200 or better, Windows 95 or later, 32MB RAM, 40MB free HD space, 640 X 480 SVGA display set to 16-bit colour (thousands), 4 X CD ROM. To run the videos on this CD ROM, you will need to instal Apple Quicktime Version 4 on your computer (contained on CD ROM).

results.title: Lore of the land
results.brief_description: This CD-ROM was created with assistance from the Cinemedia Mutlimedia 21 Fund by Fraynework Multimedia, a not-for-profit website, video and multimedia production house established by the Sisters of Mercy, Melbourne Congregation. The work is a documentary and interactive exploration of issues of identity, belonging and reconciliation in Australia. It names the land as that which settlers and indigenous peoples share in common, both as a physical resource and as a symbolic mediator of the spiritual. The user is taken on an interactive journey of discovery structured around five areas: Experience, Indigienous Culture, Land Issues, Understanding and Discovery. Content includes a detailed timeline dating back 60,000 years, summary and analysis of legal judgments, interviews, songs and paintings. The Discovery ‘pathway’ is a game where participants travel through the landscape collecting icons and artefacts. The CD-ROM has a linked website and encourages users to keep a journal of their thoughts but can be run without these components.

results.title: Lords of the wild
results.creator_credit: Grainger Television Australia and Greg Grainger
results.brief_description: This is a superb documentary featuring every species of bear around the world, and their fight for survival. Contains images which seemingly show that bears, as a species, are thriving; the truth is somewhat less attractive. The polar bear is the only species surviving in sufficient numbers in the wild to make it relatively safe, some of their darker cousins are staring extinction right in the face.

results.title: Lord Siva danced
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and Sarah Erulkar
results.brief_description: An introduction to Indian Cclassical dancing, showing four types of dance which have been part of Indian culture for centuries. Indian classical dancing is a vital part of Indian mythology and religion, tracing its origins to religious rituals and performed as a form of worship. Indian dancing has its own grammar, the language of the dance having been developed to a point where every movement of the dancer’s body is eloquently expressive. As in European ballet, dancers begin their training as children, and dancing becomes their life. The first dancer introduced in this film is Ram Gopal, one of the most famous Indian dancers. The dance he performs illustrates the manner in which various highly stylised movements, known as dance phrases, express what might be put into words to form a phrase; it is from such a movement that the film takes it name; the dance performed by Ram Gopal is in the tradition of south-eastern India. The second dance, performed by Shevanti, is typical of the dances of the north-east of India. It doesn’t tell a story, as Gopal’s dance does, but simply invokes and expresses a mood. The third dance by Rajeshwar is an example of the Kathakali or dance-drama of southern India and tells the story of bees and the lotus flower, entirely in terms of movement of his face and hands. All these dances form part of Hindu culture. The fourth dance by Chandupanikar has been preserved under Muslim influence in the north-west of India. The final dance is created from the movements of traditional classical dancing. Photographed by Keki Mistri. Commentary by Sarah Erulkar.

results.title: Lord Rutherford
results.brief_description: An historic film of Lord Rutherford, pioneer in atomic physics and winner of 1930 Faraday Medal. New Zealand born Lord Rutherford discusses the structure of atoms, means of breaking up the stable elements, transmutation experiments, the rise in new departments of chemical knowledge and the ultimate structure of matter.

results.title: Lord of the rings
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Fantasy Films, Saul Zaentz and Ralph Bakshi
results.brief_description: J. R. R. Tolkien’s massive three volume saga tells the story of how a few brave individuals manage to avert the Apocalypse by their boldness, chivalry, self-sacrifice and faith. Ralph Bakshi, America’s foremost new-style animator, translates this “impossible dream” into a full-length cartoon in a way that respects Tolkien’s story and inspiration, turning a literary classic into a magical visual experience. A large cast of mainly British voices, including John Hurt’s, excites the discriminating ear as much as the movie enchants the eye. Peter S. Beagle co-wrote the screenplay with Chris Conkling.

results.title: Lord of the flies [a discussion]
results.creator_credit: Country Education Project and David Zweck
results.brief_description: Dennis O’Hearn of Melbourne University discusses what Golding is doing in his novel “Lord of the Flies”, how he goes about it, how successful he is, and using key passages from the book, helps students to see the text in its proper perspective.
results.description: Dennis O’Hearn of Melbourne University discusses what Golding is doing in his novel “Lord of the Flies”, how he goes about it, how successful he is, and using key passages from the book, helps students to see the text in its proper perspective.

results.title: Lord of the Flies
results.creator_credit: Allen-Hogdon Productions, Two Arts, Lewis M. Allen and Peter Brook
results.brief_description: A group of schoolboys crash on a remote tropical island and revert to the laws of the jungle to survive. However, when savage emotions split them into two warring tribes, hate turns to bloodlust, culminating in a shocking murder. A frightening adaptation of Nobel Prizewinner, William Golding’s novel.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen-Hogdon Productions, Two Arts, Lewis M. Allen and Peter Brook

results.title: Lord of the bush (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Lord Alistair McAlpine, entrepreneur and Treasurer of Margaret Thatcher’s Conservative Party is opening Broome for Tourism. Examines the issues that have been raised including Aboriginal land rights and the conflict between tourist developments and conservation. Interviews colourful Broome identities and their reactions to the changes. ** PLEASE CONSULT WITH SENIOR MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY, AS PERSONS WHO APPEAR
